data.author: Ron Wechsler

data.text: Almost every country in the world has bad elements and the relative ‚Äòvalue‚Äô of the bicycle in each country amends the relative risk and hence your vulnerability. However, I would say with general precautions on your part your risk or vulnerability is low. Key to all this is the general respect cycling travellers are held and admired too. My basic advice would be never to display any wealth at all. You are a poor cyclist with little to your name. Make your bike and gear look old dirty grey and worn. In the end it‚Äôs just stuff, so if you are robbed let them have what ever they want. I‚Äôve been robbed twice and persuaded them both times that money is all that is worth taking. Carry a fake wallet with a few old cards and a chunk of cash in it. Give that, get it done and get out of there. Most importantly think ahead, plan ahead, set up your night camp stealthily and early if you sense things are not right however keep riding, moving is your greatest protection. Overall however keep it all in perspective this is not something to worry about. Go with an open mind, an open heart and a positive attitude, the world is full of beautiful places and wonderful kind people, but be street wise and in the end smile be kind and play dumb if the chips go down. You are going to have great time!
data.author: Simon Dodding

data.text: Just cycle
data.author: Maurice Kruytzer

data.text: Theres is always risk. Some places - big cities- are usually the riskiest. You have to find out the things you can do to minimise the risk. The only thing i ever had stolen on my trips was the bike in central paris - a known bad places for bike theft. None of my gear was stolen though because everything was back at the campground. After this for my trip to new york - another risky place for bikes, i bought a bike lock that weighed 2 kgs and would need an angle grinder to cut it off. I wont taking it on every trip just for places like paris, new york, london, amsterdam and probably Barcelona and maybe other parts of spain.

data.author: Paul Williams

data.text: I have an almost $12k in Sony camera, lenses, etc. In all, They add an extra 13kg. I don't worry about it. Been on the road for 5 years. I avoid big cities but if I must, I take my camera in to grocery stores but 2 of the 3 GM lenses are in the pannier. Thieves won't risk opening your stuff. They are opportunitiest. If they can't grab and dash, the won't. You can get ortlieb locking system for panniers. No one knows what is in your bags. No one expects a bike tourer to have much of anything worth while. Avoid taking it out in bad areas where beggars or other shady desperate people are if you have a bad feeling. Travel photojournalist go to pretty high risk areas. Have your camera insured and make sure they will cover you for any type of theft or robbery and get the details how to file the claim and what will be needed when you are abroad.

data.text: The stupidity and immaturity of these responses are astonishing so I'll play along: Please, come steal my camera. The insurance will get me a brand new camera! This one has been beaten up. The GPS tracker in the camera or the ones hidden in the bike will send the police straight to you. Don't forget that the high tag value changes the crime from a misdemeanor to a felony which mean longer sentencing and prison, not a cushy jail. Lmk when and where we can arrange this. I'm on my way to Portugal so I can go anywhere you'd like!

data.author: Gareth Davies

data.text: This is the ineffectiveness of expensive Equipment Because no matter how excellent quality it is, it will never be good. It's not good... It's not good that even your expedition is not over, it has created an unnecessary image of concern in the conscience of the travelers. Even if at the end, no kidnapping has happened. Unwanted events, may or may not occur. But the worries are certain, along the way. For me, despite having the ability to afford expensive things, I intend not to use them. I will choose cheaper or moderate items. Not for better usage, but for transparency. if i were you , NO

data.text: Gaffer tape to cover up the brand names, and make it look ugly and ragged do the tricks for me when I am with $$ camera gear for a job in the ghettos. If you don't need it for a job or to make money with it, leave it home, enjoy your tech free time. The way I see it, Even if you are traveling to the friendliest places, and staying with the humblest people there is no need to tempt them to do things they normally won't.
data.author: Lawrence Liang

data.text: Where I live in the Midwest people will take things off your yard and claim it as their own. Dogs inside fences have been stolen and if a car isn't locked it is an invitation to burglars. Even locked boxes bolted to trucks have been broken into as well as restaurants where copper pipes are taken for scrap metal.
